author: mrabino1
content:
In light of the ropsten TTD joy from last week and thinking ahead for the merge, what if we were to select an excessively large TTD.. and start date... and then apply an exponential decay per second such that rather than waiting for the TTD to increase (which will happen but unknown what happens if the hashpower drops off), the TTD would be constantly decreasing.... I put the thinking in bash.. granted, not artwork.. but you get the idea.. https://gist.githubusercontent.com/mrabino1/4f4cf068845b4e219cfc86c04ca59c5f/raw/e643d493c0ff2d46b476146402ee62741da277a9/ttd-decay.sh

and if we want it go faster.. we just modify the coefficient of the decay (e.g from 99% to 95%)..
 
I know it is late in the game for such an implementation.. had we not had the joy from last week, this wouldnt even be needed..

author: sky.cactus
content: I think it is too late to change the TTD strategy barring a major security bug found.  That being said, I think the ideal scenario is one where we can predict approximately when the merge will happen.  Maybe I'm misunderstanding, but it feels like this solution would result in more uncertainty?

author: mrabino1
content: well from my eyes it removes uncertainty... as it would be reducing the merge TTD trigger.. as the actual underlying TTD is increasing... we just dont know how fast it will increase... so having the TTD decay down to match in my eyes, bring more certainty..

author: mrabino1
content: for example.. if we used mainnet TTD  then times 2...  if we applied a known date in the future to start the decay... and then had the decay be an aggressive 97% or even 95%...  then even if the hashpower cut in half... the decay would continue as it is based only on time.. and it would intersect and trigger the merge....

author: mrabino1
content: point being... is if we go down the path of publishing a TTD... (the real one).. .we might have the hash power leave... at which point, there might be wisdom is coordinating an update to that TTD.. to whcih some will get that message and some wont...  so maybe it is easier to publish a matrix of days and TTDs (if we dont merge).. but at that stage.. a decay in the TTD is not epic code... it si just setting a huge TTD .. a date.. and decay factor..

author: potuz
content: I agree with <@496267636082999316> this may have been a good strategy to follow given that miners essentially only weapon is to remove hashrate. It is also very simple to implement, having TTD instead of a constant function of block number it should be a decreasing function. But I also agree with <@301186049323958275> that's too late for such changes. The method in place is secure

author: mrabino1
content: the largest concern is that miners "could" cause havoc... as the TTD could be set too high... (and thus take too long)... and then as good actors.. we then coordinate to reduce it to something more likely to occur... (closer in the future).. .and then as a result a bad actor then slams the hash power UP.... before the node operators have a chance to really update their setup with the appropriate TTD... better question (and this is my ignorance) might be how much spare hash power is possibel... or even furture, what happens if half of the network thinks the merge has already happened.. and the other half doesnt... (which is precisely what I am trying to avoid)
